utterances.text: Yes, I know that. I'm very… I am.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: And that's something you'd like to break out of that shell, or that safeguard that you've been hiding behind.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Part of me does.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Part of you does. Ok, ok.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Part of me says, “No way”.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So it really is a very ambivalent, two-way thing. I suspect it's been pretty comfortable, um, behind that safeguard; it's more of risk if you break out. Is that part of it?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I, I can almost, well I was going to say I can almost go back to the point where I really built up that safeguard in me when my marriage was going bad. Over five years ago and I could feel myself, and I know I did, I withdrew and I’ve been withdrawn ever since. It's kind of like, “No more. I don't want any more hurt.” So…

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uhm, hmm, it's just too damn risky, taking the possibility of being hurt again. And you've withdrawn from that for a long time.

title: Rogers’ Transcripts, Volume 12, Kathy Interview, page 55

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: Uhm, hmm. See, and I've been aware of this for a long time too, but I never go beyond the awareness level.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So that the knowledge isn't new, it's the um, question of what you do about it.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right, that's right. How can one stay safe and still be open?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: The way you shake your head makes me feel, “I don't see any way.”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I don't, I really don’t. If I did, maybe I probably would have done it a long time ago, but I don't.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Just seems kind of unbearable to, to be, open with a person and yet feel safe.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I, I think I'm a pretty open person to begin with. And uh, everything is fine in a relationship as long as the focus does not turn onto me.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I see, I see. If you can keep the focus on the other person you're ok.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right. And the focus on me up to a certain level, but not in the romantic kind of a way. A friendship, I would value that.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: But love, you want to, keep that at arms length.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: But you know, that's important though, because um, if a person doesn't want to really be your friend, how can you have them for a lover?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Not quite sure I get that. You mean friendship is a necessary first step, is that what you're saying, or…

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It is for me.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: We've gotten to the point where I won't go beyond.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uhm, hmm, that's what I was sort of thinking. You've thought your way this far, but then where do you…

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I've laid the cards out and that's all I want to play.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So that, in this relationship it's like in your other relationships.

title: Rogers’ Transcripts, Volume 12, Kathy Interview, page 56

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: That's right.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It goes so far and then, “Let's stop. That's as far as I want to go.” If you go any further, there's a risk, isn't it?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Yes, it is.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: And I think your eyes tell me you're feeling that risk right now.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So here I am. I feel like saying to myself, “Well you got this far. It's not so bad.” It's all right; I make the best out of it.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It's all right up to this point.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Yeah, right.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So let’s laugh it off.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Yeah, make a joke. Talk about something else.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Could, very easy to run away from yourself.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: See, but that's it. I made a bargain with myself. There's two parts: the part that understands and it’s all right, and the other part that's scared silly. But the part that understands isn’t going to force the part that's scared. When it’s safe enough, I'll be kind to myself.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: And let the scared part come out when, when you’re ready for it, when…

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: When the scared part feels ready. It’s as if part of me is in a cave away from the rest of the world. But it cert-, I certainly can't come out of that cave, unless I know that it’s all right, that there won't be a lot of pain to greet me. What's the sense in coming out? So it’s up to the best of me to make sure that there are nurturing people around me.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: And when you feel safe enough, either in this relationship or with other people, then you can let yourself come out of the cave and let the scared part of you emerge.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right. That's why, that's why I value the friendships with men and with other people. I don't care for the rest. Not to say that I don't need it, I do, but I need the friendship, and the safety and the security of that first. I, um, took a trip not too long ago and I met a man that I had known years and years ago, only very briefly. And I met him again I went out with him. And he was such a lovely person, such a kind person, and a very ... a very good person.

title: Rogers’ Transcripts, Volume 12, Kathy Interview, page 57

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I'm, I'm really interested in that experience, when you were away from him, then there was just a little while, when it felt safe. And you could perceive…

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: When I was driving.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Yeah, when you were driving and you could perceive yourself and the whole situation, I guess.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I could perceive, it doesn’t have much to, it did have to do with him, but I could perceive myself, and my closed-offedness. And at that time I was open, and I had that perception of myself and that awareness that I had been closed. And that, when I was driving through that canyon I was feeling very open and now I could have my understanding, and it was a1l right.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: You let yourself for that time come out of the cave.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Yeah, yes, it was great. And then he came to see me. He flew in to see me a couple of weeks ago. And um, I felt, see I was aware I had this memory of that opening up and so I felt more guarded.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Ah, is that right.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: But kind of slowly unpeeling layers, or slowing coming up.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: But somehow, having, having come out of the cave, you were afraid you might come out of the cave too easily.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Too, yeah that's right, that's right.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: “So, watch out, be careful”.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: You sound like a very tender, vulnerable part of you that lives in that cave.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I think my most tender part.

title: Rogers’ Transcripts, Volume 12, Kathy Interview, page 58

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: My most tender part.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Your most tender part. Uhm, hmm. Uhm, hmm. Uhm, hmm. It's really a very precious part of you that you keep in the cave

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I, for a long, long time, I’ve had the feeling of hopelessness of ever coming out. And do you know life is an existence without all of you…

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: …all of you.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Yeah, I see.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So, you, the hopelessness, I gather is because you know you're not living with all of you. Part of you you're keeping well hidden.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Well guarded. And it isn't really living, unless you can live it with all of you.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right, it's just doing things, just doing things. The part that, you know, that I consciously avoid are the arts. The things that I love, music, theater, paintings, that kind of thing.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Those are the things that touch your feelings.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I don’t get to the core.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Ok, things that touch your feelings or touch the core of you, those you want to stay away from.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: They got, they get too close, too close to this very tender part of you.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I’ve reached another stop.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uhm, hmm, but you felt safe enough to let out a little bit more and now it’s come to another stop.

title: Rogers’ Transcripts, Volume 12, Kathy Interview, page 59

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: I have to give equal time to all of my dimensions. We just have, I just felt, you know, in touch with my vulnerability, but now I’m feeling angry.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Like, “It’s none of your business…”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: …what I'm feeling.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uhm, hmm, what am I doing getting that close to the vulnerable part of you? “Damn it, stay away.”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That’s right, that’s right. What do you want to do that for?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uhm, hmm. Uhm, hmm.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: You've got other things to do.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So you’re putting up all kinds of guards against me, and striking out, “What the hell are you doing”, and, “getting so close to the vulnerable part of me, why don’t you go do something else”, hmm?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's the part that keeps me lonely.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uhm, hmm. So that, that pushing away part, that kind of angry, “Get away from me” part, is what keeps you very lonely.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It's like I don't really trust that I can trust you to know that. I can tell this and that. You may feel a little something about it, but what then? You know, I mean you know, “It's a nice story, so, big deal, something else to do”.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: What I hear is that, is that you feel that I don’t really care, just a story…

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Just something… but what if I do …

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: But what if I do care.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I want to make a joke and say, "Aw, go on." You know, um, I'm a nurse and, a psychiatric nurse, worked in a psychiatric hospital last year. One of the big things there, the patients got a lot of points if they would talk in group. I mean everybody wants you to talk. You know,

title: Rogers’ Transcripts, Volume 12, Kathy Interview, page 60

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: And so now, I talked.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: You've earned some points.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Yeah now I earned my points, that's true. But, um, I think that’s the fear of everyone. It’s not so much revealing themselves, but being cared about. That's my fear. That's my fears after I've revealed myself, “Who cares?”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It's uh, when you've let out a tender part of yourself, then it’s damned important to know, “Does this other person care? Does it make any difference?”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: My husband used to say he cared, but it was just words, it was words. He um, I think he cared as much as he could care but, he had so many conflicts inside of himself that he didn't even see me as a person. Didn't even see me. It's not that he didn't want to care. It's that he couldn't, he was too busy with himself. But I understand that. And I understand that with other people, too. But see I just can’t go around revealing myself all the time to people who are just too busy with themselves.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uhm, hmm. You need a response, you need a caring, you need to make a difference to somebody.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's it, not to someone who’ll say, "Oh, well, Kathy, I really care," and then I don't see them for a couple of years. Or, "I'll call you" and then they never call. You know, when I first split up from my husband, I would go to these different functions, not with a date, but with friends, and meet a man and he'd say, "I'll call you". And for a while there I'd be sure that I wasn't home, because I couldn't stand to know if he didn't call. And that way I didn't know if he didn't call, so there was a possibility that he had called. But I wasn't home, so how could I know. So with that, that, that vulnerable I was really in touch with it.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It makes so much difference to you to know whether the other person is going to really respond. “When they say they care, do they care?”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right, caring people, will call you, or drop by, “How's it going?”, that

title: Rogers’ Transcripts, Volume 12, Kathy Interview, page 61

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: And that's not enough?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: No, it would be enough, if they would do that. That'd be just great, that would be just great. I don't think I really want that much from another person. The morsels are fine, but I'm not even getting the morsels.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uhm, hmm, it isn't as though you want a whole meal, it's that…

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Yeah, I mean I could work up to it all right. That's why I think with this friend it was nice. And may have gone back in but I felt myself, come alive a little bit. A little bit of magic had come into my life, and that was nice. And I'd rather not come out all at once and run back in. I'd rather come out bit-by- bit and stay out. But see the thing of it is that, and like we're talking now, a little bit, or I'm thinking about the focus of the relationship, it has to be this male-female kind of thing. And, um, I don't think that what I need to do is to come out and have love, and then, think about a male-female relationship. But I don't know how I can come out too much without a man .

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's kind of a, contradiction, in a way. A dilemma, it's a dilemma. But you feel what you want first is a relationship with a person, only it helps if it’s a man.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right. It must be a man. Or…

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It isn't just better if it's a man, it's a necessity.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It must be a man, that’s right, because that's where my fear is.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So that's where you fear is, a fear of a relationship with a man. And yet, you'd like to be able to really come out of the cave first, before it became a man- woman, sexual relationship, or anything like that. Is that what you're saying?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I'd like to have a caring relationship. And its kind of funny, it's like a little girl wanting a man to take her out of the cave, and, care about. I'll put it back on me, I feel like a little girl. Someone to care about me and to know that I'm comfortable and that I'm all right, and then ask for himself.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: And then ask?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: For himself, of the relationship.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: But first, you'd like to have a man come at least to the entrance of the cave and take the hand of you as a little girl and lead you gently out, caring for you. Then maybe, other kinds of things might happen.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: The little girl is the non-sexual, being. That's right, “Don't use me

title: Rogers’ Transcripts, Volume 12, Kathy Interview, page 62

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: The little girl, the little girl will grow up if you care enough, for her.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right, and can respond as a woman, if the other is there.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Can you tell him that? Could you tell him that?

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I'm confused, do I tell one man that, or is that what I…

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I was thinking of this, this one man.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Oh, this individual.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Oh, I think I could tell him that, I know I could. But you know, I start putting him down. I know that's just, my sister told me, she said, “That's just because you're scared.” Because I told her the kind of man I would, I thought I would be comfortable with, and he is this kind of person. And then I start telling her all these bad things. And she said, "Nobody would be perfect. You would do this with anyone, some." But with this person I think I could.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Maybe you could let him know what you need.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I'd like to be able to carry that over. I suppose maybe, maybe I'm glossing that over or something, but I'd like to carry it over in my relationships with everyone. To get what I need from the relationship, and not focusing in on the other person. See, I think the way I am I'm the perfect nurse, the perf-, you know, anything for somebody else. And that's fine, focus in on them any time. But on myself, like I'm too scared to do that. Like that's a no-no. But I'd like to be able to do that, focus in on my own needs, first. But I feel kind of selfish when I look at it that way. I fee1 like a taker instead of a giver and that's got a negative, connotation.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: You're so much a nurse that when you even think of saying, “But I need this for myself.” that seems kind of wrong, selfish.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: “Wait a minute, you're the nurse. What is this?”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: “You're supposed to be caring for the other person.”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right.

title: Rogers’ Transcripts, Volume 12, Kathy Interview, page 63

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: But once in a while you realize, “I'd like to care for myself, first.”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Seems awful.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Just to say that.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: “You're so naughty, just thinking about it.”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Just to say that, seems, “What a selfish person I am.”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: “Terrible, awful.”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I feel wicked, but I enjoy it. I'm enjoying thinking about it.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It's fun just to imagine, “I might want something for myself, first.”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It's really a lovely fantasy to be completely narcissist, completely self- centered, and into pleasure, and into comfort.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Just being good to yourself.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: But in a way, you know, in a way I am being good to myself by keep that vulnerable part of me away until it's safe. Because not everybody would be good to you, not everybody would be kind. There are people who would use you up, and not bat an eyelash, and not even think about it.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: So you have a real respect for your, for your instinct for preserving yourself.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: You can't trust everyone, not everyone would care.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I was just smiling, I was thinking, but I care.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Uhm, hmm. I do care.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: “I care for myself”.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I like caring. I like it. I like caring for myself, and not giving away every part of my, just because some Tom, Dick, or Harry wants it.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: “I really prize myself, and I'm proud of that. I'm not going to just give myself

title: Rogers’ Transcripts, Volume 12, Kathy Interview, page 64

utterances.speaker: client
utterances.text: That's right. It's nice to have that feeling of caring for myself, that's good. But you know since Dick died, I was thinking, I could die tomorrow. But I'm not doing, see I've closed it off, if I could figure out some way of doing that, then, you're smiling , so that'd be just great.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: To be able to care for yourself, and yet open yourself up to life, and somehow that also tied up with the realization that, “You know, death will come one day.” You'd like to live before you die.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right, I want, I saw a card one time that said, “Born, and then died.” And you open it up and it says, "In between, he lived" or something like that. Deep down inside is the, pleasure, experience of pleasure and joy, those kinds of experiences. I've been happy. I have fun. I do enjoy my children, but it's on a limited level.

utterances.speaker: therapist

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: But joy is on a deeper level, you see, so… I want to say, "But how've you been lately?" .

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Well, “Lets change the subject.” .

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Yes, “How's your wife, your house?” all that.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Um, it'd be pretty nice to just, run away from some of this.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It would, yes.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Well let’s just have a rest for a while.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: I'm impressed with the fact that when you need a rest, you really take it.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: Oh, thank you. I was thinking my humor comes to the rescue, “Give me a breather.”

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: It's one of the ways in which you preserve yourself.

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That's right; I had a dream one time. And I dreamed that I was on a sled with two other girls, and we were going down a snowy hill. And we were going

utterances.speaker: therapist

utterances.speaker: therapist
utterances.text: That must be it.

utterances.speaker: therapist

utterances.speaker: therapist
